title: Loch Earn Walk Route

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / A85 at St Fillans
images.caption: A85 at St Fillans. Heading west along the north shore of Loch Earn, towards Lochearnhead. The railings on the left are to guard the tailrace of St Fillans hydroelectric power station.

images.title: Anthony O'Neil / Spoil Heap from St Fillans surge shaft, from the Girron
images.caption: Spoil Heap from St Fillans surge shaft, from the Girron. The large dome of rock and earth on the right of the picture is the spoil from the excavation of the shafts connecting to St Fillans Power Station on the lochside below. Other tunnels bring water from the surrounding hills to this point to provide hydro electric power generation for the community of St Fillans. The raw debris from the excavation is gradually being assimilated into the hillside as grasses and heather take over.

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Cup-marked rock above St Fillans
images.caption: Cup-marked rock above St Fillans. Hills south of the loch which is in the background.

images.title: Anthony O'Neil / Track above Glentarken Wood, St Fillans
images.caption: Track above Glentarken Wood, St Fillans. From here the track bends sharply and rises a further distance to the site of the Surge Shaft (of St Fillans power station) which collects and delivers the head of water to drive the turbines.

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Moorland and Burn
images.caption: Moorland and Burn north of the loch.

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Loch Earn and lower Glen Beich
images.caption: Loch Earn and lower Glen Beich from Meall a' Mhadaidh.

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Western end of Loch Earn from the Glen Ogle trail
images.caption: Western end of the loch from the Glen Ogle trail. The Glen Ogle trail is part of the dismantled Stirling to Oban railway: This used to be considered one of the finest views from a train in Scotland.

description: Explore the eastern end of Loch Earn and climb to a lovely viewpoint on this short walk. You can start the walk from the car park on the St Fillans Road just to the east of St Fillans. From here you can climb up to the viewpoint above the loch, passing through the woodland of St Fillans Park. There's splendid views over the beautiful loch to Ben Vorlich from this elevated spot. After taking in the views the route descends towards St Fillans before following the lochside road back to the car park. To continue your walking in the area head to the western end of the loch at Lochearnhead. Here you can pick up the trail to Glen Ogle . The shared cycling and walking route runs for about 8 miles along a traffic free path following the course of the former Callander and Oban Railway from Loch Tay at Killin to Loch Earn. Also to the west is Loch Voil where there's some lovely waterside trails to try. The epic Rob Roy Way also passes the loch. For an easy walk head east to the town of Crieff and try the delightful stroll through Lady Mary's Walk .
